item.title: Continuous Function
item.description: Given [[notes/Topological Space|topological spaces]] $\mathcal{X}$ and $\mathcal{Y}$, a function $f:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}$ is continuous if the inverse image $f^{-1}(V)=U$ of an open set $V$ of $\mathcal{Y}$ is an open set $U$ of $\mathcal{X}$.

item.title: Exact Inference
item.description: Given samples from a probabilistic model of a system, a frequent research question is to infer certain other properties about the system, or otherwise reduce the uncertainty in the sampled information - as in sensor fusion problems.

item.title: Exponential Families
item.description: An exponential family of probability distributions is associated with a set of functions $\phi=\lbrace\phi_\alpha:\mathcal{X}^m\rightarrow\mathbb{R}|\alpha\in\mathcal{I}\rbrace$ called the sufficient statistics, for index set $\mathcal{I}$.

item.title: Gaussian Belief Propagation (GBP)
item.description: With an understanding of Gaussian algebra, [[notes/Graphical Models|PGMs]], tree decomposition, and variable elimination, it becomes apparent that GBP is nothing more than a clever application of the distributive law.

item.title: Gaussian Mixture Model
item.description: Consider a multinomial random variable $X$ with values in $\lbrace 0,1,\dots,r-1\rbrace$ that specifies the choice of distribution from a collection of $r$ Gaussians parametrized by $\lbrace\mu_j,\sigma^2_j\rbrace$ for $X=j$.

item.title: Gaussian MRF
item.description: A Gaussian MRF is a [[notes/Graphical Models|markov random field]] whose edges represent the elements of a precision matrix.

item.title: Graphical Models
item.description: There are a variety of graphical models, which explicitly represent the structure of a joint PDF. Three popular variants are described below.

item.title: Homeomorphism
item.description: Given [[notes/Topological Space|topological spaces]] $\mathcal{X}$ and $\mathcal{Y}$, a function $g:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}$ is a homeomorphism if it: is a bijection is [[notes/Continuous Function|continuous]] has a continuous inverse.

item.title: Ising Model
item.description: In statistical physics, the Ising Model is classically used to model the directions of “spin” in a magnet. It is an example of a [[notes/Graphical Models|graphical model]] associated with an [[notes/Exponential Families|exponential family]].

item.title: Manifold
item.description: A manifold is a topological space that locally resembles Euclidean space near each point.

item.title: Topological Space
item.description: A topological space $\mathcal{X}$, also denoted $(\mathcal{S},\mathcal{T})$, is a collection containing the empty set, $\mathcal{S}$, and an associated topology $\mathcal{T}$ - a set of neighborhoods (subsets) of $\mathcal{S}$.

item.title: Variational Inference
item.description: When a problem is called variational, think approximate. When [[notes/Exact Inference]] is intractable, we consider a variational approach.
